frameDefinitions: An Experiencer is involved in a bodily injury to a Body_part.
An Agent affects a Patient in such a way that the Patient (or some Subregion of the Patient) ends up in a non-canonical state.
An Entity is undergoing a change in age typically associated with some deterioration or change in state.
The words in this frame describe situations in which an Agent or a Cause injures a Victim.
A Cognizer makes a judgment about an Evaluee.
In this frame, the Patient, an inorganic item, undergoes a chemical process caused by another entity, which renders it less useful, desirable or stable.
frameExamples: I think that I <t>hurt</t> myself pretty bad back there.
Rod saw his father <t>beating</t> his mother.
JUDGMENT:  She <t>admired</t> Einstein for his character.
The metal was <t>corroded</t> by the water.
listRoleDefinitions: The location on the body of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> where the bodily injury takes place.
The being or entity that is injured.
The time when the harming event occurs.
The place where the harming event occurs.
The conscious entity, generally a person, that performs the intentional action that results in the damage to the <fen>Patient</fen>.
The entity which is affected by the <fen>Agent</fen> so that it is damaged.
An event which leads to the damage of the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> damages the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the location of the scene where a <fen>Agent</fen> damages a <fen>Patient</fen>.
The <fen>Entity</fen> which is undergoing aging.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> ages.
This role indicates where the <fen>Entity</fen> is located.
<fen>Agent</fen> is the person causing the <fen>Victim</fen>'s injury.

The <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured.  If the <fen>Victim</fen> is included in the phrase indicating <fen>Body_part</fen>, the <fen>Victim</fen> role is tagged on a second role layer (see 3rd example).
The <fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the location on the body where the bodily injury takes place.
The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that inflicts harm on the <fen>Victim</fen>
<fen>Time</fen> identifies the time when the harm-causing event occurs.
<fen>Place</fen> identifies the place where the harm causing event occurs.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the judgment. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
Evaluee is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Patient</fen>  is corroded by the <fen>Cause</fen>.
<fen>Cause</fen> identifies an animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that corrodes the <fen>Patient</fen>. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>.
The individual that corrodes the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cause</fen> corrodes the <fen>Patient</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Cause</fen> corrodes the <fen>Patient</fen>.
listRoleExamples: I cut <fex>my finger</fex> on the envelope.
<fex>The squirrel</fex> abraded <fex>its</fex> tail as it twitched nervously in the confined space.
So you cut your leg on the window frame <fex>at six o'clock</fex>, correct?
She fell and hit her head <fex>out in the playground</fex>.
<fex>The crash</fex> dented my car pretty bad.
<fex>Jolosa, who</fex> broke a rival player 's jaw, was told to model his play on the England striker.
Someone bashed <fex>him</fex> on the back of the head with a heavy smooth object.
Someone bashed him <fex>on the back of the head</fex> with a heavy smooth object.
Riot police in Nairobi clubbed four women unconscious <fex>on March 3</fex>.
Boys  are punched <fex>at school</fex> for payback
<fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
The boss appreciates <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
She viewed him with an appreciative <fex>gaze</fex>.
<fex>The metal</fex> was corroded by the water.
